Not sure what they consider add-ons, because any other place that sells burritos will tell you that it comes with, rice, beans, sour cream, guacamole, salsa.  They might even throw some chips on the side for you.

This place is garbage!  Don't eat at Chipotle!
author: Eddie M.

description:
This Chipolte is in the ground floor of my building and is very convenient. They are amazing at getting the crazy line through but not always nice about it. I will say, they have gotten much better in the customer service over the years which has been good since they used to be down right rude.

My gripe is that you would think there is a shortage on lettuce. I usually get a salad and ask for extra lettuce. At the end of the line is the lettuce for burritos and tacos... because they are so chincy on the lettuce at the beginning (for a salad) I usually have to ask for more lettuce. I'm ordering a salad for goodness sakes... give me some freaking lettuce! What's up.
author: Ashli R.

description:
Assembly line burritos made with simulated enjoyment.  They give you the simple instructions right before you order.   Apparently you can fax your order.  It's only a matter of time before they release Chipotle API 1.0 in perpetual beta to allow you to place your order online.   Around the same time that happens, they'll start replacing the workers with robotic equivalents who simulate enjoyment just as well as their human counterparts.   Shortly after that, maybe, you'll be able to simulate consumption and take a pill to give you the illusion you've just had a Chipotle Burrito.

I'm sorry... I've had Chipotle burritos before at other locations but coming to this FiDi location on a weekday lunch felt like I'd entered a New World Order caloric consumption factory.

Welcome to the future?   No thanks.
author: David O.

description:
Donde esta el sabor?

I was halfway psyched when this shxt shack opened up next door to my office.  I remember other Chipotles in my past as being halfway decent, and proximity is everything for the downtown luncher.  Yeah, I can give it multiple stars because the ingredients seem reasonably fresh.  But somehow here these good ingredients add up to less.  Where the hell if the flavor?!  

Personally, I don't mind the lame decor, much.  Have just a slight problem with the assembly line-style limited menu.  Have a few problems with the lack of wayfinding that consistently finds newbies walking in the front door and up to the register visible before them, because there's no signage indicating that the long-ass line forms to the left.  Can even say that it's a plus that there's some outdoor seating, and skylit seating indoors.  Which is all to say, it only halfway sucks, so it's two stars instead of one.  But Mexican food without soul isn't even as justifiable as Mickey D's.  Please make it close soon so that some 3-star plus restaurant can take over the space.
author: Ted R.

description: Yummz. I appreciate the extra corn the guy hooks me up with.
author: Margaret R.

description:
Surrounded by all the culinary goodness all around me, I should be ashamed of going to a chain, but hey, for me, this is a step up from McD's or Jack in the box.

Why do I come here? The first reason is their hot salsa. It's really hot. The second reason is that it is somewhat healthy fast food as long as you dont get the chips. So, there.

Anyway, the lines are long, but it moves really fast. The servers are very friendly and efficient. The food is really fresh and tasty. 

The only downside is that this lunch cost about $10. :(
author: July N.

description:
I know reviewing a chain like Chipotle is about as futile as reviewing a phone company or PG&E or Muni....it really doesn't matter because they will never read the review and take anything into account, but alas I felt the need.

Chipotle gets a major ding for charging $2.00 for chips and salsa, sorry I'm simply stunned by that, everywhere else they are free.  

The burrito was sort of tasty, but $8.87 for a veggie burrito and chips is BS.
author: G L.

description:
I come here when I need a quick and easy lunch... and usually that's the case unless you get stuck at prime time lunch hour. Come here early to avoid the line that literally is out the door and sometimes down the street. Sure they go through the line pretty quickly and they even have someone taking orders/doing payment via CC in line... but it's still a good 15-20 minute wait. Come here at like 11:30 or come after 1:30 to avoid the wait. 

I've had problems here before but I wrote to the manager and they quickly remedied the issues, so they get a thumbs up from me now since I haven't had a repeat in problems.

Love the carnitas burrito bowl and even the salad option. mMm... and this place seems pretty clean even though it's so busy. They got seating inside, out, and even stools at the windows. Good spot for lunch!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I just devoured a barbacoa burrito and now I am ready for a nap.

Don't wait IN LINE! Place your order ONLINE!
Order online, pay with a credit card, when you pick up your food at the special window don't forget to smile smuggly at all the people waiting in the line that  is typically out the door.
I ordered 7 items for a meeting, online, and sashayed out the door 30 seconds after walking in!

Is this real mexican? No
Is it delicious in it's own way? Yes
I really love the lime flavored rice!
The menus are plain and simple: Taco, Burrito, Bowls and Salads
Your choice of chicken, steak, carnitas, barbacoa, veggie
There are other options to choose from as well WHOLE BEANS, guac, salsas, cheese, lettuce, fajita veggies... you are encouraged to customize.
Honestly what I like is when I buy a burrito from Chipotle's I feel full and satisfied - money well spent.
author: Edi B.

description:
BLAH....
not good, not terrible.   definitely a fast food burrito.   i will not be returning, but I wanted to know what the hype was all about.

there was a piece of mystery meat in my burrito that was NOT steak and had a really gross bone in it.
the rice was bland and tasteless. 
the salsa was OK.
author: Katharine A.

description: I love Chipotle and it is right next to my office in SF, but I hate the long lunch line.  I was thrilled to discover online ordering.   My company has ordered online several times and I have ordered online individually.  The purpose is to avoid the long line and have your order ready and all you have to do is pick it up.  Problem is, is that it is never ready and you end up waiting as 15-20 minutes.  Items are usually missing or wrong....It's better to stand in the long line and get what you want.
author: Jen M.

description: Chipotle changed their guac recipe. I'm no longer a fan. It's gross and tastes like the guacamole from Costco. I'm halfway out the door to go to Whole Foods to satisfy my guac cravings.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Some days you will just feeeeeel like grabbing chipotle. You must know what I mean!! Because you have too!!

My preparer was soo kind and charming. Efficient. No complaints. 

FYI mild salsa is not spicy at all so if you want more kick get the next one!
author: Veranna N.

description:
I get ragged on by friends for coming here when the Mission and their infamous taquerias are not too far away. Mind you the same people who rag on me for going to Panda Express when Chinatown is a few blocks away. The reason I don't go is simply because I've yet to be impressed by something in those districts. The atmosphere and food tends to be touristy, ghetto and/or bland. 

The reason I come to Chipotle is because of flavor. Granted when I used to live out in the mid-west, I loved going to Chipotle mostly for their signature cilantro rice. 

If you are a local reading this and still feel the need to recommend a good taqueria in San Francisco--please shoot me a message to let me know.

The best part of this location is their pick-up window. I can just order up something on their iPhone app and bypass the entire long lunch rush line, pay and leave with no fuss.
author: Terry C.

description:
(YaY for my first yelp review)

I LOVE chipotle!!!
i live right around the corner, and go here at least 3 times a week!

its not the best customer service, but hey - its an in and out kind of place - id rather have a fast taco then some chica i dont know asking me how my day is

it kinda sucks that every chipotle in san francisco is in the same sqaure mile, but still, chipotle will always get 5 stars from me!!
author: Tia M.

description:
Bypass the long ridiculous line.

Go to their website and place your order instantly online.

Opt for the trio of crispy grilled chicken tacos - customize your order any way you please.

Pay by cc online and choose a pick-up time.

Walk over to Chipotle and head directly to the pick-up window and my order is always there ready for me.

Donezo.

IT'S THAT SIMPLE, PEOPLE!  LOOOOOVE IT!

I do this at least once every other week.  Really.
author: Carmen Y.

description:
This line is crazy long everyday! 

Went there at 12:00pm and there were over 40 people in front of me. It took 20 minutes in order to place an order. CRAZY! 

The staffs were efficient and friendly in this location. 

I got the Veggie Taco. It was OK. Everything was fresh and the corn salsa was pretty good. 

I hope we will have another Chipotle in Financial District. The line is just too crazy!
author: Liza T.

description:
Fresh, cheap, and custom made. Lovee the fajita burrito bowl, and love that the line at Chipotles everywhere moves fast.  

You've just gotta go and experience it to become a fan. Most people love it, some hate it, some just can't get over the fact that it was connected to McD at some point. But it's good, healthy ( errr i think.. sort of) and delicious! So just get up and go already!!
author: Shafaq C.

description: Worst wrapped burrito ever -- it instantly fell apart all over the place. The taste didn't make up for it.
author: Olivia P.

description:
I finally walked down here one day and tried their steak burrito bowl because all I hear about and see people eating (at work) the bowl. So my curiosity got the best of me and I wanted to see what the fuss was about. The line was long,  but decent. I was able to pay for my food in the line before I got to the front. A total newb I tried my best to be quick as the workers seem to be getting annoyed at me. One of them actually looked like he wanted to fling the rice at me. Hahaha 

When I got back to my office and gave it a go, I wasn't too impressed. The steak was a little salty. And the combination of flavors and food was just okay. I'm not sure I would go on my own again, may be go when it comes up.
author: Jamie L.

description: I think this is the best Chipotle in SF - the one on O'Farrell street is okay but it is smaller, more crowded, and not as high level of service.  I have actually gotten to know the people who work at this one and they are always nice.  While I almost always do take-out, this location is very large and they have good outdoor seating.
author: Alex C.

description:
Food is great as in all Chipotles.
Problem with this one is that it closes very early - 8 PM, but they don't have guacamole after 7 PM, and it doesn't work on holidays. 
For example it was closed during the Pride Parade, while people were lining up at the other food chains. 

I go to Chipotle in Nordstrom (5th & Market) or AMC Metreon (4th & Mission) as they work everyday until 10 PM.
author: Maria Y.

description:
Have you ever had your burrito made by a white guy wearing a pooka shell necklace?  It's a serious paradigm shift.  But I love fake Mexican food.  I also love real Mexican food.  Basically, I like spicy starches and melted cheeses any way you want to serve them to me.  So I am not offended by this cracker establishment.  The reasons I eat here are twofold:

1) It's next door to my office.  

2) Some dude who I hope never to meet personally is such a Chipotle superfan that he has developed a nutritional calculator of their products:  http://www.chipotlefan.com/index.php?id=nutrition_calculator.  Sure he's crazy, but he's helping me take control over my bootang.  Forgiven!
author: Rosie W.

description:
I love the food at Chipotle!  Although the chicken is just okay, the carnitas and barbosas are awesome.  The corn salsa is also super-flavorful.  The price is also very reasonable - and you got to love the qualifty of ingredients you are getting. 

Only complaint about this location is that the line is always out the door at lunch time!
author: Mark M.

description: Right across from work, and hits the right spot. Not very expensive for a place in the financial district. The burrito is satisfactory and juicy! Don't come right at lunch hour though unless you're willing to wait in a long line! It goes by fast, but it still goes out the door which usually means at least a 7-8 minute wait.
author: Junel S.

description:
Unfortunately, I have to give this Chipotle bad marks, purely on quality of food alone.

The Chipotle itself is actually okay, though there are not many seats with window views on the inside. There is a patio area, which makes up a little for the indoor seating, but depending on the weather, that isn't much better. Fortunately, the staff is very friendly, and fairly efficient, getting through the usually long lunch line fairly quickly. Standing at the end of the line will usually take 15 minutes before you are paid up and ready to eat.

The real sadness was with my burrito. I always get a chicken burrito with a variety of fixings, and I assure you, when I have ordered this burrito from any other Chipotle, it has been absolutely fantastic, and has led me to favor it over many authentic San Francisco-style burritos in The Mission.

But something has been wrong with the burritos from this Chipotle. The chicken just doesn't seen to be cooked as thoroughly, and the beans are far too dry. I would have chalked this up to random chance, but every time I visit, I'm disappointed in the same way.

Thus, I can't recommend this particular Chipotle very highly. I might venture out to the other FiDi Chipotle to try my luck there, but with the variety of other lunch options available, Chipotle might have to wait for me at another location.
author: Derek L.

description:
I don't care what all you haters say: I love me some Chipotle. This one looks like every other one in the country. And it produces a similar quality of food. 

Is it the best food I've ever eaten? No. Is it reliable and flavorful? Hell yeah. 

Situated near big important buildings and between two Muni Metro/BART stops, it's spacious, has a great wrap-around-line (some don't), and a plethora of soda fountain machines to ensure your addiction to Diet Coke.

Barbacoa burrito bowl with spicy salsa is where it's at!
author: Jared S.

description:
Food = okay
Service = fast.  People are a bit rude though.
Seating = okay.  A bit too 'urban' for me...lots of shiny metal surfaces.  Cold.

Prices = okay for what you get.

I'm just not impressed.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I recently discovered this place, having opened recently in Alameda, CA.  It is a very good restaurant. The food is delicious and wholesome.  It really fills you up. I chose to eat here again, at the 525 Market location, in San Francisco.  It was that good.

I love how they have a "subway" style build your own burrito hot bar, right in front of you. The ingredients are right in front of your eyes, and look absolutely delectable.  The service is super fast!  Excellent.

I'd normally give it 4 stars, but have to drop 1 star for below comments.  Sorry.

I do have some complaints.  I notice that the premium Mexican "fresh mex" type restaurants, all have high premium prices, compared to places like Taco Bell, etc.  Obviously, the food is 10 times better.  I also notice they normally have a full sized salsa bar at most of these places, (La Salsa, Baja Fresh, etc.) and they give you quite a section as part of your purchase.

Chipolte, inexplicably, charges for salsa, chips and Guacamole.  I'm confused by this. I can sort of understand the charge for Guacamole, tasting it is out of this world, and it is made fresh, not canned or bottled, to the best of my taste buds ability; but charging for salsa chips and salsa, seems to outlandish.  For the record, the charge for a bag chips and guacamole is $2.40 at this location (525 Market Street) and I believe it was $1.90 for salsa  and chips.  I didn't see a separate price for chips alone, and wonder if it's not available or the same price for chips and salsa together.  They definitely didn't do the normal chips included with a burrito option, and I paid for all chips and condiments I received.  My total purchase price for a delicious chicken burrito and chips and guacamole was around $9.50.  

I would normally not complain out loud on a review board, but it just happened to be that somebody complained behind me for the charge for Guacamole, I think $2.40, which he had included on his burrito.  So no lesser charge if you include Guacamole on your burrito or tacos.  Seems a trifle high.  He comments out loud to the clerk.  I should also add, that when I requested Guacamole, at the restaurant in Alameda, the table clerk told me up front, that the charge was an additional $1.90 (the price for chips and guac was a slightly lower $1.90 at the restaurant in Alameda, but $2.40 in the one in San Francisco).  I very quickly declined since I planned to buy a separate Guacamole and chips for $1.90.

Other than that, I thought it was awesome!  I know they served beer in the Alameda location, but unsure about Market Street address. I'll have to check again, next time I'm there.
author: William C.

description:
It's been awhile and I was needing a burrito and this place was closest so I figued I'd give it another try. Still the same experience.

Food: not bad but a poorly rolled burrito (first two bites were nothing but 'filling')

Service: not great. My god, I can't hear at all what they are asking (loud music) and nothing on the board indicates the options you are screaming at me (is there just one type of salsa? is it hot or not? what types of rice do you have? oh, you just yelled that guac is $2 extra? yes, I appreciate the smile as you yell). I had to ask 2x what she was saying and the I told her but by that time she passed me on to the next person who was shouting...ended up with not really what I wanted.   Basically, this is all no problem if you come here all the time and you jam through here, but if you're like me and you rarely come here, the experience is just plain crappy.  Seriously, every more traditional burrito place in SF (Gordo's, anything in the Mission, etc.) is less crazy. You end up feeling that they just want to get you out of their eye-sight as fast as possible w/no real care for the food.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
I ate here for the first time today after watching that reality show the restaurant's founder is on currently, to see what all the fuss is about. The line was very long when I visited at 1:30 p.m. on a Tuesday, but moved fairly quickly, and the service was efficient. I was surprised to see the calorie counts featured so prominently on the menus. I'm already pretty savvy about such things myself, but I think it would be especially useful for people to see exactly how much fat they're getting in the chips and the vinaigrette, not to mention the guacamole, cheese, and sour cream (none of which I got). Edit: I've now been told that calorie counts are required to be displayed prominently by chain restaurants with more than 20 California locations.

My vegetarian burrito was tasty. I would have liked to see more options for tortillas (whole wheat, spinach, etc.) but I know from experience at similar places that more choices would slow down the line. Same for rice; it was quite tasty, but a brown rice option would have been great. Overall I'm satisfied with my meal and experience.
author: Pax G.

description: Great location. Outdoor seating area when the weather is actually nice in San Francisco.  It's a large location with plenty of seating.
author: Eduardo G.

description: Seriously? $10 for a burrito? I was starving from a morning out in the field rather than stuck at my desk, so popped in there - rather, waited for 15 mins at 11:30 AM - for a mediocre burrito. I count 5 pieces of chewed up gristle they call "steak."
author: Mi M.

description: Chipotle closest to work, same as most of the other Chipotle's.  If you've been to one they're all pretty much the same.  This place gets busy as lunch time though, I've seen the line out the door.  But I have the benefit of strolling in around 3pm where there's hardly anyone there.  I get my steak bowl without the wait.  The service is good, there are plenty of seats and the place is clean.  If you work in the area this is an ideal spot to hit up.
author: Jeremaine R.

description:
I love Chipotle, don't get me wrong, but they need another restaurant in the FiDi or something.  This one is just tooooo busy during the lunch rush.

"Order online, don't stand in line", their website says, but today I had to wait in line 10 minutes just to get to the online order window.  If I'd wanted to spend 10 minutes waiting in line, I wouldn't have ordered online.

So, by the time I get to the window, get my food, and get back to my office, it's 20 minutes past when I wanted my order to be ready, and my burrito was correspondingly lukewarm.

IMO, when the manager is at the online order window and sees that the line stretches back to the patio doors, he ought to offer something -- free drink? free burrito? I shouldn't have to ask for compensation when you fail to meet your service promises.
author: Ryan S.

description:
The fact that I am here three times a week (since I forced myself to cut down) would probably make this a 5 star review, but I have to be honest that my addiction for Chipotle doesn't make it the best Mexican food out there. It is reliable , filling and really tasty for a great price!!!!

This location is clean, has outdoor space and the people work hard to get you in and out. I LOVE standing in line as it is part of the whole Chipotle experience.  If you are in a hurry, order online and their pick-up window people are just as friendly and efficient as the front line.

The food is always fresh and no matter how many times I say I'm getting something different; I end up with Steak Burrito black beans, no rice, spicy salsa, sour cream, chees and lettuce.  HEAVEN!!! 
Now I just have to master not swallowing the burrito nearly whole and enjoying and savoring it!!!
author: Jason B.

description: This is the second time I have come to Chipotle and they have run out of chicken at lunch time ...it's 12:30 and let's see how long it takes ...
author: Joe R.

description:
Normally love this burrito. 

Today, Sutter location wasn't taking orders online. So I placed an order here for an 11:45 pickup given I needed to grab and go for a meeting. 

Show up at 12:00, they can't find it. So, they question if I placed the order to the "right" location. Get out my phone, scroll through my gmail and find the receipt for them. It's the right location. 

They look again for a couple minutes, come back and say they can't find it but will make a new one. Bummer. Ok fine, looks like I will be waiting. I ask if there is something I can eat in the meantime, no dice.

I had already paid for it via the Chipotle app, and I needed lunch, so I cancelled my meeting. Waited about 15 minutes as they dealt with other orders/people. Finally came out and gave me mine. 

So, 20 minutes late and it would have been nice to discount the order, or at least offer me chips to munch on.

Walked away frustrated.
author: John H.

description: i think it's funny that three different people are in line to make your burrito.  i like chipotle, it's yummy.
author: Erik M.

description:
I'm a tough critic when it comes to Mexican food, and this falls under the category of Americanized Mexican food. When it comes to taste, Mexican "food chains" fall short every time - Chipotle is decent, but there are just too many other authentically delicious options in San Francisco, in my opinion. The only exception to that would be if you're looking for healthier alternatives to taqueria food. Chipotle's burritos are also fresher and ligher, and while I personally don't prefer that, I think it's great to have healthier options out there for those who want it.

I've had their carne asada tacos and their burritos here. I didn't have high expectations, and they were are as good as I imagined - which is just okay. I won't go back, just because there are too many better-tasting options out there.
author: Mariela D.

description:
Sometime during the spring of 2008, I ate lunch here with three friends.  We all like Chipotle, and we certainly don't need to read Yelp reviews to figure out whether we like one location better than another one.  The fast food industry, for better or worse, aspires to consistency.  You get the same tasting food at Chipotle, wherever you go in this country.

On this day, however, as we all dug into our burritos, all conversation stopped.  Something was different.  All four of us were having the greatest Chipotle experience of our lives.  I can't explain how any single Chipotle burrito (or in this case four) is better than any other Chipotle burrito.  It just was.  No matter how the chain may strive for uniformity, there are always going to be elements left to chance.  Perhaps the doneness of the meat, perhaps the seasoning of the salsa.  I don't know.  But on that glorious afternoon, all of the dominoes in the universe had fallen into place for us to enjoy the greatest four burritos that had ever been made in Chipotle history.

I've returned to this same location many times since.  We all have.  It's not the same.  That perfect moment will never be recreated again.  And I'm okay with that.  Someday, though, years from now, I will sit my grandchild upon my knee, and tell them of that perfect day in 2008, when grandpa was still young, the robots still served the humans, and the four of us had the most awesome Chipotle burrito experience of all time.  No one can take that story away from me now.  No one.
author: Chris H.

description:
Yay! I 'm a fan. I came here with my friend for a quick lunch, the line was super long so I didnt like that but a guy was coming around and taking your orders if you pay credit and he gives you the receipt right there!
I had the steak fajito bowl...delicious!!
My friend had the same but without rice. The steak is pretty spicy so I wouldn't put any extra spice on it if you can't handle it...like me the weakling.
There is always a place to sit too. 
Yay for Chipotle
author: Lana K.

description:
I love me some Chipotle and I've mastered the ordering process. I always get the vegetarian burrito bowl, no I'm not a vegetarian but like to be one here because you get all the toppings with chips for $7. If you add meat its $10 or so.   Anyways I love their rice, salsas and guacamole and boy they are not skimpy on the good stuff. Their chips are perfectly salty with a twist of lime. If you want to go to this location I recommend BEFORE 11:30 otherwise its 40+ deep! 
Oh and shout out to Oprah, I had forgotten about this lunch option. Oh and shout out to the owner who is way more food conscious than the rest of us...
author: La C.

description:
RICE!!!!!  I mean, seriously.  Was there anything else in my burrito besides rice?  Oh, wait...I may have spoken too soon.  Yes, yes, there it is!  A tiny shred of pork!!  Low and behold - there IS something else in there.  Oh...and a huge ass piece of avo.  People, a huge chunk of avocado does not equate guacamole.

All this translates into a big fat disappointing mouthful of RICE.  My life is ruined.  

Well, not really....but still.
author: Megan H.

description:
My co-workers LOVE this place, as do I. Order your meal online & bypass the huge lunch line...and sometimes that line oozes out & into the street. Don't people ever learn that planning shaves so much waiting time?

There's really only a few ways to get your meat in: burrito form, taco form, salad form, or all-by-its-lonely-in-a-bowl form. Either ways its all the same thing, just a quick switcheroo w/the ingredients.

I usually opt for the steak tacos, reducing the rice & beans, adding lettuce, corn salsa and fajitas veggies (green bell peppers & onions). I always ask for their salad dressing (zingy Chipotle sauce) to go with it... mmmm, good lunch. Chips are good, too. Very crunchy & addictive.

Download the iphone app. You'll be just a finger tip away from picking up your order without waiting in line.
author: Joy A.

description:
Now I'm sure lots of people, myself included, would argue that Chipotle is hardly a "Mexican" grill, but that doesn't mean that Chipotle doesn't make a mean lunch for the FiDi crowd.

I'd only been to Chipotle about five times in my life before I started the Atkins diet about two months ago.  I avoided Chipotle because I knew a meal there could pack in the calories.  But now that I'm on Atkins, I love eating at Chipotle!  I order a salad, which comes without tortilla and rice, and further strip it of beans.  But I get to have whichever of the tasty meats I feel like having - Carnitas and Steak Barbacoa are my faves - plus sour cream, salsa, cheese, and guacamole.  

This location really gives you a generous heap of guac.  It's definitely worth the $1.85.  YUM.

Tip: arrive before 11:35 to avoid the line that can snake a good 50 feet out the front entrance.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Normally I would give any random Chipotle 5 stars... their burritos are so good (mainly because of the rice), and the chips and guacamole are perfection together.  That being said, this Chipotle just doesn't seem to know how to handle the big crowd sometimes.  I admit, they're fairly efficient, but they still get over-whelmed.  So, what do they do?  They try out the online ordering system... this has so much promise!  However, upon using it for the first time, I arrived at the restaurant only to have to wait 15-20 min for my food (as did many others around me).  What's the point of setting a pickup time if you can't meet it?  The line actually moved faster.  They should really just have a dedicated person making pickup orders, instead of having the regular line workers making them.

Anyways, delicious food that I can never resist... but have some kinks to work out with the online ordering.

C arnitas burritos are the best thing ever from here.
H ot and fresh, everytime.
I nflux of business folks at lunchtime make the place pretty hectic.
P ossibly the best chips & guac combo out there.
O nline ordering pick-up process needs some improvement.
T en bucks for a very filling meal.
L ots of seating, both inside and outside on the patio.
E at until your stomach is ready to explode!
author: Kenny L.

description:
I dunno..I just can't get in to Chipotle. The burritos I order never seen to come together properly. The last one I ordered had cold cheese and all the ingredients were separated so that I got huge mouthfuls of plain ol' beans or worse yet, sour cream...and I HATE when that happens. It's one of my worst burrito pet peeves. 

The good news is that the portions are hefty, it's pretty reasonably priced and it works for good lunch/drunk food.
author: Julia N.

description:
Perfection. A simple word. Albeit hardly attainable. Chipotle has effortlessly meandered and found its way to this word by crafting the ingeniously scrumptious burrito bowl. The flavors compliment each other so wonderfully its absolutely remarkable. 

Is it crowded? Yes. But as a previous reviewer has pointed out, the line moves pretty fast owing to the dynamic assemblers who are deft and super quick at dishing out the course.  

Its not the most authentic you would find, but its fabulous.
author: Natasha I.

description:
I have to average it out. The salad? 4 stars (weird chicken). The burrito? 2 stars. Like  manparts, big is good but I don't care what ANYONE says- there is such a thing as too big, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise. And that advice is free.

The quality far surpasses that of the stinkerias I usually bypass. I would totally go back for the salad. If I didn't have to stop mid-chew to spit out each piece of fatty, chewy, gristly chicken (who knew chickens had gristle?). So...I probably won't go back unless I'm really hard up for a salad, everything else is closed, and I have some time on my hands for chicken-spitting. Apparently their chickens are raised right and they cut their heads off in a nice way, or at least that's what the signs on the walls would lead you to believe. I don't know...my chicken didn't seem too happy...
author: Autumn K.

description: Standard Chipotle.  But they do make margaritas that are so strong you'll swear you're at an actual Mexican food joint!
author: Jammir G.

description:
Best Chipotle in SF.  I eat at Chipotle more than anyone should, and out of the four I've been to (each on multiple occasions), this one is the most generous with the ingredients, has the best employees (you will not get undercooked chicken here or wait 10 minutes while a new guy breaks three tortillas wrapping your burrito).

That said, it's still Chipotle.  Four stars.
author: John M.

description:
Y'all ever see that South Park episode with Billy Mays and Chipotlaway?

"Billy Mays here!!! If you're like other Americans, you love to eat Chipotle, but you hate all those terrible blood stains in your underwear... But Chipotlaway makes your underwear clean and ready for more. Stop buying new underwear every time you eat Chipotle!!"

Gross...

Just like their food...

The Baracoa meat is OK, beans are lukewarm, the rice is bland and the cheese looks old...all mixed together in a cold tortilla and you can guess how it tastes...

...yep you're right, it's ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!!!

I don't know why.  From growing up in Socal and eating great Mexican food everywhere I have absolutely no reason to like the food here...the stuff served at Chipotle probably makes the Mexican food Gods turn in their graves.  Somehow, someway, the mad scientists at the mother company, McDonalds win again.  An amazing concoction of mediocrity in a bag that somehow tastes amazing...I don't get it...I really don't get it...but I won't stop eating here.
author: Nico M.

description:
Much like sour cream itself, an excessively liberal use of the term "Mexican" to describe food that is not, essentially, Mexican, is a culinary faux pas and does nothing to endear the public to true Mexican cuisine.

But in the microcosm of franchisor-franchisee restaurants that serve "Mexican" food, this place makes a damn good chicken burrito bowl.  The quality of meat is excellent, and all ingredients are fresh; the guacamole is actually really tasty.    
  
It is also one of the few restaurants within walking distance of my office that is open after the end of the lunch hour, which is great when I'm stuck late at the office (until 8 p.m.). 

And I use the word "great" in an excessively liberal fashion.
author: James M.

description: Called in an order to be ready at 2:50 (not a busy time you would think) but when I got there it wasn't made yet. Had to wait for the cashier to ring up everyone in line before she even told anyone about it. Tried to offer me a free bag but I was holding a reusable one. It's probably the hangry coming out but I was not amused.
author: Carolyn T.

description: I love Chipotle burritos but at this location (and occasionally at others) the chicken in the burrito is sometimes nasty - it can be fatty/tendon-y/chewy and other times gritty and dry, like I'm eating bits of gristle scraped off the side of the grill. I'm not fussy about chicken but both of these extremes are so nasty I can't finish. It's come to the point where going to this Chipotle is a liability, will I get a delicious meal or something so gross I can't eat it?
author: Hunter P.

description:
Great food, worth every penny! The menu is simple and the ingredients fresh and hormone/antibiotic free. The burritos can be high in calories so if you're watching your waistline stick with a salad- which are also delicious.

*I'm from Denver where Chipotle started and is extremely popular, especially with the college-aged crowd. I was thrilled to find the downtown locations.
author: Jen N.

description:
My name is Jeff and I love me some Chipotle. Yeah I know this place isn't authentic or anything but good lord, they bring the heat.

I always get the same thing. Chicken Fajita burrito with guacamole and corn salsa. Holy crap this burrito is AWESOME. The chicken if flavor full, cilantro lime rice (hate it or love it) is delicous and I love that I can get peppers and onions instead of beans. But one of the best ingriendts has to be their guacomole. This is my most favorite quacomole. I am sure they put MSG and all sorts of perservaties in it but I honesly dont care becasue it taste that good.

This location has an online pick up order system which I suggest you use since the line can get 50 people (no joke) deep.
author: Jeff P.

description:
I freakin live off this place!! We all know Chipotle is to die for and ever since we moved our office to The Hobart Building, this has been our spot. The service is amazing. And the Restaurateur, Evange, knows how to make you happy. A few weeks ago he threw us (and 15 of our friends) a Chipotle party...on him! What a guy. We try our best to pay him back with referrals and getting lunch there most days. Also they are extra heavy on the guac which I love and they cook their peppers and onions a little longer than other spots which gives them this perfect tender taste and feel. You feel like they are slow roasting peppers right in your mouth. Love it. 

Keep it up Evange!
author: Scott D.

description:
Seriously, dude ass.  Who cares what the CEO makes?  Who cares that Mickey D's used to be in bed with these guys?  Who cares about any of this?

If you don't like the food, lemme know.  If the people at this particular location are nimrods, lemme know...

I can personally attest to the people at this particular location being very competent and caring as far as their job goes.  They get the job done and keep the environment cool.

I've always loved these few things about Chipotle:

- relatively cheap, mostly organic food served quickly
- gigantic share-with-my-girlfriend portions
- 80/20 good to bad music ratio on the overheads
- 70/30 nice to lame employees in most locations (I've been to Chipotle in like five states)
- really cool artwork

This particular location serves anywhere from 200-350 people during the lunch hour rush, with a line-up stretching around the building.  If you're not one of those people, or even don't ever wanna be, that's cool... but don't expect me - or anyone else with a mind of their own - to give you extra points for it because you hold some vague "moral" assertions about the place.

It's classic American dream material... guy has a passion for food, guy works in restaurants in Mission District, guy likes what he sees and soaks it in, moves to Denver and starts his own shop.  Like a decade later they're all over the place, bringing arguably more fresh, organic food to the table than ANY "fast food" restaurant you could name. 

I prefer the chicken burrito bowl, rice, extra onions and peppers, lettuce, guac, double hot sauce, cheese if I'm feeling randy.  Their chips are AMAZING, as is the guacamole, but I don't feel like having a cardiac arrest, so I'll be skipping on those delicious, salty wonders.

This store in particular is set up really well, nice people who take pride in running this fast-paced machine of a store.
author: Blake C.

description:
This place confused me.  

Where was I supposed to be?  The corrugated aluminum wall paneling reminded me of the Sonora Desert, but the sculptures on the back wall were Mayan glyphs.  Were there any Mayans here?  The kitchen staff looked Aztec to me.  The music seemed to be some loud Caribbean disco, except it had accordion where the steel drum would be, and the lyrics were sometimes sung in French.  I didn't know if I was supposed to feel like I was in Tijuana, Cabo, or Cancun.  Wherever it was, maybe I haven't been there yet.  

I ordered a burrito de barbacao, with pinto beans, cheese and fresh salsa.  A small Diet Coke with that brought the bill to just under $8.  The rice was non-sticky, which was a nice touch, and while I ate the burrito it slowly dissolved and disassembled in my hands.  Good thing the tables were metal, like the walls!  

Even though I knew I was on Market Street, I expected to smell suntan lotion at any moment.
author: David D.

description:
I just ate lunch here and I, too, am confused.

Is this white food for Mexicans or Mexican food for whitey?
author: d s.

description:
OMFG...has anyone read or even heard about the book "Eat This Not That"?!  It's basically a book that tells you which major fast food joints serve up some of the worst foods for you, and which ones you could replace as "healthier" alternatives (e.g. eat a McDonalds Big Mac, not Burger King's Whopper Jr.)  So, I was browsing through it at Target the other day and discovered this interesting tidbit (http://health.yahoo.com/experts/eatthis/139/the-20-worst-foods-in-america): Chipotle's Grilled Chicken Burrito is loaded with almost 1,200 calories and 50 grams of fat!!  I don't even want to know how many calories and fat grams are packed into those Mission burritos, it's best if I not know, and I don't foresee Mission taquerias posting their nutritional facts anytime soon.

Unhealthy or not, I think Chipotle is still a good lunch spot if you choose your meal wisely.  I usually opt for the Burrito Bowl or Tacos with tons and tons of their yummy mild corn salsa.  And I like their tortilla chips that are made with a hint of lime, just like Tostito's, but not as lime-y.
author: Diane L.

description:
This would be a 3.5 star review if that were possible.  First off, I'd never been to a Chipotle before.  My Yelp pal's new job is right nearby and she had a craving, so off we went.  

I wasn't crazy about the IKEA-like decor or the too-loud oldies soundtrack, and I can't call what I ate authentic Mexican food, but it was unexpectedly tasty.  You can't really go wrong with a salad that has more sour cream and guacamole and cheese than lettuce.
author: Andi T.

description:
It's hard to find a place to meet T & B for lunch that's near my office in the Financial District.  Most of the lunch places around there are busy and loud and full of people who are not in a baby state-of-mind.  But the Chipotle at Market and First has high chairs and a friendly staff that loves it when we bring B in.  They even brought a high chair over sua sponte the last time we ate there.  I've had to beg for one at formal restaurants, so I was pleasantly surprised that a fast casual place would do that.

The line is very long during lunch rush, but they do their best to get you through quickly.  And this location does not have the (awesome) kid's menu.  But B gets plenty to eat out of my bowl and T's burrito.  I love that their meat is naturally raised, and the food is delicious.  You might do better coming in before noon or after one, but even during the rush we can usually find a place to sit.

By the way, this location is not open on Sundays.

High chairs?  Yes
Changing table?  Didn't check (sorry!)
Stroller-friendly?  Yes. 
Noise level?  Pretty high during the lunch rush, but you can still have a conversation.
General baby-friendliness?  Surprisingly high.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
In college, Chipotle was my prime lover. Now, having recently graduated, I obviously still crave their awesome burritos/bols from time to time. It might be the fact that the one I used to frequent was in a more suburban town and that the only one I know of in San Francisco are the two in the financial  district, and seriously - the change in setting really is the main reason why this review isn't getting five stars.

For taste, Chipotle is bomb. I'm a huge steak fan, but you HAVE to get chicken here. Their tortillas are also chewy and awesome, the corn salsa is a must - especially if you're a corn fan, and the guac is *almost* worth paying the ridiculous extra 1.70 for.

Stars are deducted because I have constantly been brushed off because . . . what? Because it's the Financial district and I don't stroll in with business attire on? Or because it's San Francisco? Either way, not cool. On several occasions, the makers behind the counter have blatantly ignored me and continued chatting amongst each other when I was obviously standing in front of them. Or if I'd ask for a little more sour cream or cheese, I'd get an exasperated face in return - dude, what? I'm the one paying almost six bucks for a burrito that's not even from the Mission.

Whatever.

Come here for the awesomeness that is Chipotle - the culture, the quirky messages on the cups and the nice, clean, Californian ambiance, but don't expect top notch service . . .  unless you have your 2k power suit on. I didn't know there was a dress code for a burrito place. Jeez.
author: Betty W.

description:
I usually like Chipotle.  In fact, it's one of those guilty indulgences that I don't normally admit to people (until I find out that they have the same sentiments as me).  First of all, yes, it's a chain.  Yes, it's not healthy for you.  But heck, the reason why McDonald's is so successful is because their food is fast, and yes, it does taste good.  

It's not a gourmet meal, but ask the rest of America and I am sure they would grudgingly agree (anonymously) that fat + salt = good.  

Anyway, the reason for the star is not because I hate on Chipotle now.  It's because I hate on THIS particular Chipotle.  There is always a large line, the people working there probably hate their lives and they take it out on you and your food.  I'm sorry you hate your life, but please don't make me hate mine. 

Thanks.

They slop things together and basically roll their eyes at you when you want anything else, and they treat you like a gigantic waste of their time.  Plus, my burrito bowl is usually a mess.  I'd rather spend a few extra dollars to keep my blood pressure from spiking due to the attitudes.
author: Shay F.

description:
I don't want to hear it.  Chipotle is delicious.  Don't get your panties in a bunch - this by no means is a statement on the delicousness of other burritos, it is merely a statement about the Chipotle burrito.

It is darn tasty.  And all of you people knocking authenticity?  If I ever catch you in a:

Sbarro
Olive Garden
Panda Express
Buca di Beppo
California Pizza Kitchen

...or any of an additionally long list of "abominations compared to the real thing", I will brand you an "ASS" and insist you wear a scarlet "H" for your hypocrisy.
author: Max A.

description:
It's funny that with so many Mexican restaurants in the Bay Area with better food, I still get cravings from time to time to head to Chipotle and grab a burrito.

This particular Chipotle is pretty much on par with most I've gone to. I've only visited on the weekends, when the place is almost deserted. I can imagine this Chipotle being super-busy during the work week, being right there in the Financial District.

The staff has been nice to me during my visits there, and the food still is tasty. There's not more you can expect from any Chipotle place.
author: Dennis M.

description: Close by to where I work, it's cheap, big portions, and you can pretty much get whatever here. Love the chips and guac...... not a fan of their rice. It's ok, I wouldn't go out of my way to come here. I rather go to Rubios.
author: Irma R.

description:
Nobody's really down to give this place a 5 star rating because they know its a chain.  If they do give it a 5 star rating, they might feel a wave of guilt-- 'but that's just pride, fucking with you'.

Here, after the Pulp Fiction quote, I have to make a point to say that I have always had good meals from this spot.  It's just a chain, but the management has the decency to keep the vegetables .

The only way I could give this place less than 3 stars is if they start dishing out crap burritos and salads-- but so far this place has done really well.  I would say writing reviews of chains is pointless, but if there's one that consistently good then just give them 4 stars-- and keep your 5 stars for the really hard to find.
author: L J.

description:
It's good food and even though the line can get seriously long during lunch hours, there's the guy taking orders with the handheld thingie that helps speed up your visit.

It's just that there really isn't a "wow" factor to the meals here.  It's all very basic - the same meat offerings the same filling offerings, the same side offerings as pretty much any other American Mexican eatery.  You can be a complete newbie to the Chipotle experience and still be able to navigate through their menu liike you've dined there a hundred times before.

Which can be good or bad, depending pn your dining expectations.  But when there are so many other places to eat in FiDi, Mexican included, I want that "wow" factor - that moxie that makes me feel like I've done good with my ten bucks.

Still, I'd take Chipotle over Taco Hell any day.
author: Eileen P.

description:
Went here for the grand opening last night and got free burritos.

Free shit=free star for you.

Pretty damn good food=three more stars for you.

Hoo-ray for a new place to eat close to the office when I'm working late and need to bring something back to the office to eat at my desk.
author: Matthew R.

description:
If you like crap franchises or don't want to walk the two blocks for a better option (in Atlanta) then this is your place.

Their beans seem to have stones. Their guacamole gives me tummy trouble. They are one of the only places not to offer tofu instead of meat.  Their nachos are oily. Their salsas are rancid.

On the positive side, you can marvel at how they have themed their place with semi-mayan imagery using only polished steel and wood.
author: David J.

description:
just don't think of it as 'mexican' food, per se. if you're not hung up on the authenticity thing, it's just reasonably fresh ingredients put together in a way that tastes decent for a moderate price at a place that's open after everything else within four blocks of my work except McDonalds is closed. that's pretty much it.

but why you people wait in a line that stretches out the door every day for it, I'll never know.
author: matthew r.

description: Quick, fresh, organic and local foods, with simple, fast and friendly service. Affordable and delicious fare makes this place a great spot, plus they have outside seating next to a fountain. 1 star taken off for being a chain (I prefer to support independent business)
author: Jack N.

description: Carnitas was very bland.  My burrito tasted english, not mexican.  Skip this place and go to Si Senor in the alley behind for true Mexican carnitas (and cheaper)
author: Suzy Q.

description:
So this is how disappointment tastes.

Cold un-melted cheese, sour lime-drenched rice...if I'm going to eat a 1,200 calorie burrito, it should at least be satisfying. I want to be fat AND happy, damn it.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Disclaimer: the architect who designed this Chipotle (and, in fact, every Chipotle nation-wise) is a former client and friend of mine.  So don't be hating on the design, foo!

Every time I go in, I am amazed that McDonalds owns this place.  You can see McDonalds' corporate knowledge in the efficient layout of the food prep line, but the ingrediants are high quality and the finished product is VERY delicious.

And here's what I really like: you can order online (yes, David O., right now, today), by going to Chipotle.com.  In fact, not only can you order online, but Chipotle will save your "regular order" if you'd like, so that in subsequent web visits, you need only click two or three times for the order to be placed.  I am a bit bothered by the fact that, 20 minutes after placing your web order, you're supposed to call them to confirm.  I suspect that's to prevent spam orders/fraud/etc., but it's still a bit annoying.

No one WANTS to like Chipotle---as San Franciscans, we're supposed to hate the big chains and love little burrito places scattered hither and yon across our many neighborhoods.  Problem is, Chipotle is quite good.
author: Ben P.

description:
It is astonishing to me... about this place.

Owned by McDonalds. 

This is a perfect example of corporate responsibility.

The public was outraged with McDonald's cynical and unhealthy business practices... from production, to delivery.  

So, they researched what they were doing wrong, and built a brand PRECISELY according to what consumers were asking for.

Organic, free range, fresh.... it is an astonishing and very optimistic and consumer oriented approach to business and food.

I am really proud that Chipotle is McDonalds by way of corporate responsibility.  Well done.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Chipotle is like a 3rd string veteran quarterback.

You don't want to call on him.  But then your star quarterback and backup quarterback get injured (i.e. you have to work late but not late enough that you get a per diem, or you have to work through lunch and didn't have time to brown bag).

So you call on your 3rd string quarterback.  He's reliable (i.e. it's decent, you know what you're getting, and it's open late when everything else that's fast in FiDi is closed) and you signed him without having to worry about the salary cap (i.e. a burrito will cost you $6 + tax).

A crucial part of your roster, but you call his number only when absolutely necessary.
author: Marcus W.

description:
Just had a steak burrito bowl for lunch and it was horrible.
Just because I want sour cream and cheese, doesn't mean I want huge globs of it.  Also, everything was extremely salty.  The meat, cheese, rice, chips and even the lettuce and sour cream were salty.  I chucked it in the trash.  It was truly disgusting and impossible to consume.  Never again.
I am amazed that this place has so many lunchtime customers...
author: PictureGirl F.

description:
I work near here, so sometimes when the weather isn't cooperating, I head to Chipotle for the fajita burrito bowl with chicken (no beans, cheese, nor sour cream).  

It's not bad in terms of typical Chipotle standards, I'm just upset about the portions.  This Chipotle profiles customers by gender or size.  Each time I've gone with a male counterpart , I get a smaller portion by 30%.  

I demand fair treatment for the smaller people with big appetites!
author: Miss H.

description:
Been coming for nearly two years and get my usual 3 crispy carnitas tacos to go, with pico de gallo, medium salsa, sour cream, cheese and lettuce....dont forget the chips.

always sorta disappointed by the amount of carnitas they give or don't give. plus the line is ALWAYS way too long....i thought, ok im just settling. not a good way to live life is it? 

until.....i went to the New Montgomery St. location!

Less people in line and TONS of carnitas.  The line servers are much more generous with their servings AND much faster.
author: Tim D.

description: I only come in here a few times because the line is always super long at lunchtime.  However, when I'm ready to fight the line I am never disappointed, I really like Chipotle, the food is always consistently good.  The line is long not because the service is slow it's because everyone wants to come there for lunch and it's in the financial district.  Everytime I go there, their service is efficient and goes as fast as it can go and always with a smile.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Why oh why do we all have Chipotle guilt?

Aren't there enough things to feel guilty about?  

Why do we feel so guilty for enjoying a chain restaurant?

Oh.  Right.  It's because we live in San Francisco.
author: Jen I.

description:
I love the simplicity and transparency of this place.  I've only visited once, but I was very delighted with what I got for the price.

$5.95 bought a pork burrito in a bowl (no tortilla) with a good amount of fixins'.  I didn't like the fact that stuff that cost extra was sorta mixed (in the order of things) with things that are included in the basic price tag (missed out on some lettuce at the end, darnit).  

The assembly line operation was VERY efficient ... almost too much so.  When you're on lunch break during a work day, who has time to putz around?  Crack that whip! These guys and gals are very efficient.

The food taste was par with other mexican food in the area.  At least you knew exactly what you're getting .... no mystery ingredients.

I'll be heading back to Chipotle in the future ... a simple menu with speedy turnaround is a nice backup in a lunchtime pinch for time.
author: Jamie W.

description:
My favorite lunch place.  I know - I know - this is San Francisco, couldn't I find a more original, gourmet place to spend my lunch hour twice a week?  Perhaps but I choose Chipotle because the carnitas burrito bowl is like an incredible bowl of Mexican deliciousness.  My co-workers think I have a serious addiction to Chipotle.

The line is long during the lunch hour but it moves pretty quick and doesn't stop me from loving this place.  I could probably eat it everyday if I wasn't afraid my co-workers would plan an intervention.
author: Cassie B.

description: I've had really good Chipotle burritos, and so-so Chipotle burritos. All my meals at this particular Chipotle have been so-so burritos. The meat tends to be dry and tough, and the burrito overall lacks flavor. But knowing me, when I get a Chipotle craving during the work week, I'll probably still come back for more.
author: Bella L.

description:
Damn, I'm ashamed to admit that I secretly (not so secretly) want to give this place a full five stars, but feel like I would be rightly ridiculed for doing so.  Instead, I'll tell everyone that I WANTED to give Chipotle five stars, but only actually award it three stars.  

However, if they gave me free burritos with free guacamole every time I came here (as opposed to only doing it on the grand opening) I would find a way to hack into the Yelp database and make sure that every time myself or anyone ever reviewed a Chipotle it was automatically awarded 6 stars!

P.S. Three stars is actually pretty generous considering the stingy bastards charge well over a dollar extra for guac.  Nonetheless, I really am shamed to admit that I love their food.
author: Matthew H.

description: I don't know what South Park was talking about. Chipotle is pretty good. The burrito bowl is what's up - all the taste and flair of a burrito without the mess. It's like a taco salad but a burrito and it's mighty tasty.
author: Hanan H.

description:
The food is standard mexican, nothing to write home about but very solid. However, the portions here are terrible. They clearly very consciously skimp on the helpings everything, from meat to beans to sour cream. And you have to remind them to give you sour cream and cheese every single time; it's like pulling teeth with them to give you what you paid for. This is not a gourmet restaurant, it's a major chain taqueria; I expect you to give me the portions that are standard at taquerias. 

Also, and almost as unforgivable, they use small tortillas for their burritos and don't even attempt to roll them properly. They fold the thing over, pinch the sides, and wrap it up in foil to make sure it stays together until you get back to your office, where it promptly splits open the second you unwrap it. It's not even cylindrical like a burrito should be, but almost a ball. The only way to eat it without spilling it all over yourself is to cut the thing in half. I'm not sure how it is at other Chipotle locations, but this is terrible.
author: Eric F.

description:
This is where you go when you need to dash out of the office, grab something, and dash back.  A standby.   Utilitarian.

Why it's better than Rico Mex (formerly Si Senor) - Chipotle is much cleaner.  See Si Senor's health inspections.

Why it's better than El Faro - El Faro is gross and their beans seem meaty.

Why it's better than Baja Fresh - They don't wrap their burritos in paper and then foil like Baja.  That drives me nuts.

I wish they had a rice option that didn't include cilantro.  I also wish they had tofu.  Compared to the other options close by though, it'll do.
author: Squirrel L.

description:
On the reals, FUCK Chipotle!

Seriously.  This shit is fucking disgusting.  Granted, I don't eat meat and got a "salad", so maybe their beans and meat are acceptable, so I won't give these assholes negative stars.  But um, just an FYI, lettuce smeared with guacamole and shredded cheese is not a salad.  There was no salsa, no tomato, no onion, no nothing!  Like, is that a joke?  Are you fucking retarded?  Is the concept of a salad too difficult to comprehend?

But really, let me be frank.  Part of my frustration stems from the fact that their group ordering system was far too complex for the group I ordered with.  They didn't really understand that hey, if you want chips and guacamole, you order chips and guacamole!  So they decided that hey, look, there's guacamole, how about I eat it all?  Even though they didn't order any.  UGH.  

Luckily the chips were so gross that I had no desire to eat any, so it was easy to give up the guacamole that I had ordered.  Seriously, what is up with those chips?  They're like, dipped in salt and lime and, was that a hint of vomit?  

On the plus side, I didn't pay for it, and at since I just had guacamole on lettuce, at least I won't be bloated from this pukestravaganza.

On the minus side, all of my coworkers think this stuff is really good, so we'll probably be having it for lunch again.  Oh well.  Maybe I can somehow find a way to give everything a liberal dousing of tequila to make it more palatable.......
author: Coco D.

description:
As hard as I try to like Chipotle, it just doesn't appeal to me...atleast with the way people worship it. They have the most americanized burrito, but not bad considering how gigantic the burrito is. I have always had chicken and didnt thnk too great of it, but people say the steal is excellent. 

The manager of this place is so nice seriously he will bend over backwards for his customers...awesome dood. 

Unlike some other fast food places l, they have a seperate place to put bottles that are recycable which i appreciatr
author: DessSoFresh K.

description:
I think I have to go here for lunch today. 

I try to make it to Chipotle every couplea weeks to get my chicken burrito fix. I have never been disappointed by a burrito here! I love the hot salsa & the marinated chicken is so delicious. Oh, my mouth is watering. 

You should probably come around noon or after 1 if you want a seat cuz this place gets packed with the FiDi folks. Oh and you'll hear lots of boring conversation about peoples workplaces while in line. One group of guys were talking about colleges & how Ivy League is really the only way to go. Ug thank god I don't work with snobby corporate dudes anymore! 

There is another Chipotle close by on New Montgomery (that I just recently discovered) so if the line here is out the door & around the corner you should head to the other location. You might get a seat too!
author: Erin S.

description: Friendly staff, fresh tasting food and light on the wallet! Went at 11:45am and line was to the door :(  Line moved slowly, took about 10-15 mins but once you're up, the staff works at warp speed! Ordered a veggie bowl with corn tortillas on the side - loved the fresh taste and all natural seasonings! The corn torts are sooooo good!!!! Soft and perfect for tearing and throwing into the veggie bowl for a mess-free lunch at the desk!
author: Shaw Y.

description:
Oh, the modern day assembly line of gluttony.  What a fantastic, efficient feeding machine this place is!  I actually broke tradition and had steak soft tacos today instead of the usual fajita burrito.  Because it's SO much better for me.

This location is much better for the FiDi crowd than the New Monty locale--saves me all that extra walking [slumps down in chair, takes bite of Little Debbie].
author: Daryl E.

description:
God, this place is a money machine.  I know it is a chain, but it is my very favorite among the chains...and they'll be faster once everyone figures out how to order here.

Somebody did some environmental design and customer observation with this menu.  Just the same, it helps if you know the following when the tortilla-steamer person glances at you:

1) type of dish (burrito, tacos, bowl)
2) Meat (bistek, pollo, carnitas...all are tasty)
3) Shade of bean

The burritos are a major gut-bomb...know your limits.  Drat that I'm a plate-cleaner.
author: Michael B.

description: I love Chipotle!  I was informed by a coworker to order online beforehand.  Thank goodness the line was out the door...I walked in and got my food.  I had a slight mix up with my order but the Manager Evange was understanding and made everything right again.  I will be back again!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Solid burritos and salads at fast-food prices and production time.  It's not the OMFGy-best Mexican joint, understandably, but it's solid and, if you get their bowls or salads, reasonably healthy -- 650 calories for a scrumptious chicken bol and 350ish for their chicken salads.  Just don't give into the temptation and top it with cheese.  Or get the yummy burrito wrap that adds 400 calories to the meal.

Cost-benefit analysis: There's a few local digs hiding around locally that can offer cheaper food that taste decent, but this joint's got solid EV for the masses.

Calorie-taste analysis: Surprisingly reasonable amount of calories if you get their delicious burrito bols.

Random factoid: Apparently this nice li'l McD spinoff chain has a crazy high sales/sq-ft, and their stock ticker (CMG) shows it too.  Lotsa people on this bandwagon, it seems.
author: J C.

description: I was the first customer that day in this restaurant. Tried a Veg bowl which is my fav. I asked the guy to put more rice and less beans, he was so adamant that he just gave like 1 tea spoon of rice extra. This is the first time this has happened to me in Chipotle restaurant.
author: Prasanna B.

description:
Everyone at work is seriously addicted to this place. We usually hit it up around 2pm, when the lines become manageable.

Good, fresh food. Who's counting calories?
author: Gabor C.

description:
4 stars for a chain?  Yes!  I know this is not really Mexican food, but I still love their chicken fajita burritos.  Gotta get the corn salsa mixed with mild and hot.  And their smoked chipotle tabasco sauce - yum!  I'm still looking for a place to buy this stuff for home.

There is often a long-ish line around lunch time.  But you can call ahead to order for pickup.  And they often try to expedite things by having you pay (by credit card) while standing in line.  The effort is appreciated!
author: Leslie L.

description: Steak burrito was good and almost rivals Baja Fresh, but extra cost for guac and premade nature keeps it from 5 stars.  Though this same premade nature is a benefit if you are in a rush, I guess.  I got mine with no bean or rice and requested salsa fresca, hot sauce, cheese, and lettuce.  I thought the portion was good and quality and taste of the steak was very nice.  If not in a rush, though, Baja Fresh is a better bet for this category of eating.
author: Marc S.

description:
Great burrito in downtown SF.  The burritos are huge and will fill you up for lunch and dinner.  It's located right in the heart of SF's FiDi.  Service is quick and friendly.  Good quick eats right before my classes at UC Berkeley extension.  The grub is high in calories, so be sure to factor that in before coming inside.

Their fajita burritos go great with a bottle of Sierra Nevada.  I especially enjoy their burritos with their hot and corn salsa.  Cute office girls are usually around the area, so grab one of the outside tables when the weather is nice.
author: Terry T.

description:
Sheesh.  Their lines are long and I expected a half hour wait time, but surprise surprise!  The lines moved so fast that it seems like i barely had time to read their menu.  Since I've had their burritos before, I decided to venture out and try their burrito bol.  Basically, it's a burrito in a bowl and no wrap.  

It's just as delicious and you would be amazed at the quickness of the servers.  They are dunking out food so fast that it takes longer to pay than to have your burrito up.  

What I like is that Chiptole uses white rice.  I think it's different.  Also, b/c they give you a lot of sour cream w/out asking for extra.  They don't go on cheap ingredients too.  You can tell that the ingredients are fresh. Their chicken is not dry and I just like this place.  It's cheap good food in the FiDi.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Chipotle is awesome.  The proof is in the gigantic lines that this place has during lunch time.  The speed at which they move you through the line is also amazing.  I think one of the girls in the serving line has some sort of superhuman hearing, because she can somehow hear me say "sour cream" above the din of that place, even when I can't hear myself.

Don't listen to the detractors with some abstract, idealized notion of authenticity on how a burrito place "should be".  It's true that you're not going to find any burritos like this in Mexico. That doesn't matter.  They never made any claim of being authentic.  It's good food and they use good ingredients. 

It's almost impossible to go wrong.  The carnitas burrito, the hearty chips with that hint of lime, everything is so good.

Arriving at this Chipotle after walking past all those horrible McDonalds and Burger Kings and whatever elses on Market. is like wandering thirsty in the desert for 40 years and arriving at a beautiful, lush oasis.

Just because it's a chain doesn't make it bad.
author: Jon N.

description:
I can't understand why this place is so popular. It has to be the location, and/or that you can charge it on your expense account and it looks like a legitimate lunch destination to Finance.

The food is mediocre at best. It's an assembly line of fast food crap. I've heard that it is owned by McDonald's but I could not find any information to support that rumor. More likely what the rumor meant to say is that it is the McDonald's of Mexican Food.

The burrito gives me heartburn. So on my next visit I ordered the burrito bowl and it's basically all the ingredients of a burrito slopped into a bowl with no tortilla. Again, heartburn. (I know, duh!)

The only thing good about it is that it moves fast so I guess if you are on Market St, in a pinch for lunch, and need something pronto - you could get something quick and cheap in here for like $7. The assembly line moves faster than the people so expect a bit of confusion and having order specifications barked at you several times when you get up to the register.

Also note, this is a huge corporation (out of Colorado)! The CFO reported making $600K last year. $600K!!!!!! This is the type of thing this economy DOESN'T need. Try RicoMex on Stevenson just a short walk away for better, more authentic Mexican food. RicoMex at least seems to be a local, family owned operation. Keep your $ in SF!
author: Craig G.

description:
So I came on their first day at about 3 and they were out of what I wanted and the service was kind of slow. The food was ok but nothing special. I only gave it three stars because of these reasons. In a week or two when the staff is all trained and they know what a normal day should be like and how much to have on hand I will go back and reevaluate.

Ok so I went back and reevaluated and I think the food was worse the second time around. Because of this they are losing a star.
author: Morgan B.

description:
Ever since my collegiate days in San Diego when I was first introduced to this wonderful mexican food chain, I have been in love. And this is not the type of here-today-gone-tomorrow-damn-I-loved-that-place-for-a-moment-but-now-it-sucks-kind-of-love...no, this is definitely the everlasting and unwaivering, borderline obsession type of love.

I could eat at this place everyday, and usually do. Even when I bring a lunch into work, I can't say no whenever someone knocks on my door and extends me an invitation to Chipotle. And as fate would have it, a new Chipotle has been built right across the street from where I work. Makes me think that God is telling me something.

If I had to give Chipotle a slogan, I would call it the "In and Out of mexican food." The menu is small, but everything is delicious and they give you more than ample portions of food. I have recently become addicted to the crunchy tacos, which don't make me feel as though I am carrying a Food Baby in my stomach after every meal (tends to happen with the burritos), but the burritos and soft tacos are solid as well. And since I'm a guy, I don't get burrito bowls so don't ask me about those (even though I am sure they are awesome). The service is fast, friendly, and there is always seating. And the best part is that if you have been a student anywhere at some point during your life and still have a student card, you can get a free fountain drink every time you are there.

I am sold for life...Shamoan
author: Jeff W.

description:
This Chipotle location has their process down to a science, which is no surprise considering the Chipotle franchise was previously owned by McDonalds Corp. and they were the foundation of the assembly line. But don't worry, Chipotle is free of grease filled, fried & cholesterol increasing food. I went to this particular location at 12 noon on a Thursday and the line wasn't too long, but when I got up to the counter, they were moving so fast that it made me stutter and lose my train of thought. There were literally ten people working at the counter and my burrito bowl was made and paid for within a minute...I kid you not!

I like the burritos at Chipotle, but in reality they are quite mediocre as far as gourmet burritos go. But there's something about the warm chicken burrito bowl that makes me drool on my computer keyboard as I count down the minutes until lunchtime. The burrito bowl includes your choice of chicken, carne asada, pulled beef, pork or vegetarian (avocado & sour cream), white rice, beans (black or pinto), pico de gallo, salsa, cheese, corn and lettuce on the top. If you have had a burrito at Chipotle and didn't like it, go back and try the burrito bowl, you will love it! If you are looking for an authentic burrito, go elsewhere.

My co-worker and I inhaled our burrito bowls and still wanted another one, until it finally hit us and we felt like our stomach's were about to explode. In other words, they are DELICIOUS!  

Very reasonable prices, adequate seating & you can get a free drink w/ a student I.D. card, what's not to love?
author: Elaine S.

description:
I can't really point to what's wrong with the burrito, except that it's basically served cold. By the time you put cold cheese, salsa, sour cream, and lettuce on top of a tortilla, beans, steak, and rice that were only warm to begin with, and you don't bother to then put it on a grill to heat it -- duh, you get a cold burrito!  !No bueno!

For gringo comida, there's a much better chain called Qdoba that SF doesn't have yet, but until then, I recommend Pasilla a few blocks away at Kearny and Pine.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Dear Chipotle,

Despite your long lines, I freaking love you.

My cheermates and I come faithfully each week, to indulge in your amazingness that is the carne asada burrito bowl.

Or when I'm feeling a little daring, I get the chicken burrito with pico de gallo AND the corn salsa WITH the chipotle lime salad dressing mixed in.  I'm serious...it's delicious.

But the one thing I must thank you for...is the margaritas.  There's nothing like going back to work....WASTED after just two of those lovely concoctions.

OOooo...boo...you're gonna get me in trouble.

You know you love me, cuz I love you.

That's all.
author: Vince S.

description:
I'm a fan of the food....NOT the lines. This location gets packed during lunch peak hours so prepared to wait. 

Chipotle food is consistent everywhere so if you've had it once, you've had it all. Still, I love this location just b/c it's bright, they have patio seating and it's fairly clean. The people who work here are fast so the line moves quickly.

Also I saw a pick up window so looks like you can place orders ahead of time...fun fact.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
If you haven't ordered your food online you're missing out!  
I have always been weary of ordering by fax or online because my order never comes out right!  I can tell you that Chipotle got it 100% right and it was delicious!
I must say I was very please with my accurate burrito bol! YUM!
author: Nicole F.

description:
I realize that me giving Chipotle 4 stars may lower my reviews in some people's eyes. And, I've wrestled with myself over this dilemma, but I've decided that, deep down, I really do love Chipotle. 

I always get the same thing: veggie burrito with everything (including all 4 salsas). Getting a bowl/salad/tacos is all the same price, and a burrito seems like the best deal to me. I love the crunchy corn in the salsa and mild heat of the hot salsa mixed with the yummers guac and sour cream. I never get sick of it. And, I can eat 2/3 of the burrito at lunch and have the rest for a perfect mid afternoon snack.

In addition to the addictive burrito yumminess (that bears zero resemblance to mission burrito yumminess), I love this place because I can order/pay online, by-pass the giant line, and pickup my stuff at the to-go counter. Genius!
author: Corinne R.

description:
After having lived in San Francisco for three months, I came here on Halloween for the free burrito promotion.

I'd always been a huge fan of Chipotle, but I figured having been spoiled by Mission burritos, this would be the day when I'd walk in, and realize that this big chain wasn't that good after all. I wanted to feel that way.

But it still was a damn good burrito, as much as I didn't want to admit it. Sure, it was a lot different from a Mission-style burrito, but it was still really good; they really do make an effort to use high-quality ingredients.

And despite what all the haters say, this really is one of the highest-quality fast food chains in the country.
author: Mark A.

description:
I came here for lunch with a friend today. We went at around 12:45pm, and the place was still pretty packed. There was a long line, but it cruised by surprisingly fast. The staff was efficient (always a plus in fidi) in taking orders remotely. When you go up to the "chefs," they make your burrito quick style. I got the Chicken, and my friend got the Vegetarian. They were pretty huge burritos, and the taste was good. It did not leave me super thirsty or dried-mouth (from the salt/MSG). The price was very decent as well!

This Chipotle has an outdoor seating area, which is nice to be outside on a nice day (windy today though). But if you decide to sit outside, you better be ready to fend off the pigeons in the area.
